Davis Milton Love III was born on April 13, 1964, in Charlotte, North Carolina, into a family deeply entrenched in the world of golf. ![Image 6: Davis Love III Biography](blob:http://localhost/3307afe07e4f49cf2559baa311e1b5db) His father, Davis Love Jr., was a well-respected PGA professional and acclaimed golf instructor whose passion for the game profoundly influenced his son’s career. The family later moved to Brunswick, Georgia. In addition to his parents, Love III’s family includes his younger brother, Mark Love, who has also been involved in the golfing world, though more prominently in the business and management side of the sport. ### Early Career Davis Love attended Glynn Academy in Brunswick, Georgia, where he showcased his golfing prowess by winning the Georgia State Championship as a high school senior, setting a single-round record of 66. His exceptional skills on the golf course earned him a scholarship to the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, where he played college golf from 1983 to 1985. He accumulated 6 titles throughout his collegiate career. At UNC, Love was a 3-time All-American golfer who won the Atlantic Coast Conference (ACC) tournament championship in 1984. In 1985, Love’s amateur career reached a significant milestone when he played on the USA Walker Cup team, representing his country in one of the most prestigious amateur golf competitions. ### Professional Career After turning professional in 1985, Love quickly established himself as a force on the PGA Tour with his first victory at the MCI Heritage Golf Classic in 1987. Over the years, he accumulated 21 PGA Tour victories, including a major championship win at the 1997 PGA Championship, which solidified his status as one of the elite players of his time. Love’s career highlights include two wins at THE PLAYERS Championship in 1992 and 2003. Due to its prestige and the strong field it attracts, the PLAYERS Championship is often regarded as the fifth major. His success at the MCI Heritage Golf Classic was particularly notable. He won the event five times, with his final victory in 2003. Love has been a fixture on leaderboards throughout his career, spending over 450 weeks in the Top 10 of the Official World Golf Rankings. His ability to consistently perform at a high level earned him a place on six U.S. Ryder Cup and Presidents Cup teams. In addition to playing, Love served as the U.S. Ryder Cup team captain in 2012 and 2016. Despite personal challenges, including the tragic loss of his father in a plane crash in 1988 and the embezzlement incident involving his brother-in-law in 2003, Love has maintained a positive outlook and continued to excel in his career. Love’s achievements have been recognized with numerous accolades, including induction into the World Golf Hall of Fame in 2017, solidifying his legacy as one of the game’s greats. ### Wife Davis Love III’s wife is Robin Love. They have been married since November 1986 and have been together for nearly four decades. They met in high school at Glynn Academy and have been a constant presence in each other’s lives ever since. ![Image 8: Davis Love III with his wife Robin Love](blob:http://localhost/3307afe07e4f49cf2559baa311e1b5db) They have 2 children: Alexis (Lexie) Love, a competitive horse rider, and Davis (Dru) Love, a professional golfer. Davis Love III’s Net Worth Details ------------ **Davis Love III’s net worth is estimated to be $50 million as of 2025.** His earnings come from his prize money as a professional golfer, endorsements, and other sources. ### Prize Money

| **Davis Milton Love III** (born April 13, 1964) is an American [professional golfer] who has won 21 events on the [PGA Tour], including one [major championship]: the [1997 PGA Championship]. He won the [Players Championship] in 1992 and 2003. He was in the top 10 of the [Official World Golf Ranking] for [over 450 weeks], reaching a high ranking of 2nd.[\[2\]][\[3\]] He captained the U.S. [Ryder Cup] teams in [2012] and [2016].[\[4\]][\[5\]] Love was inducted into the [World Golf Hall of Fame] in 2017.[\[6\]] Early life ---- \[[edit]\] Davis Milton Love III was born on April 13, 1964, in [Charlotte, North Carolina], to [Davis Love Jr.] and his wife, Helen, a day after his father competed in the final round at the [1964 Masters Tournament]. His father, who was a former pro and nationally recognized golf instructor, introduced him to the game. His mother is also an avid low-handicap golfer. His father was killed in a 1988 plane crash.[\[7\]][\[8\]] Love attended high school in [Brunswick, Georgia], and graduated from its [Glynn Academy] in 1982. Amateur career ------ \[[edit]\] Love played college golf at the [University of North Carolina] in [Chapel Hill], where he was a three-time [All-American] and all-[Atlantic Coast Conference]. He won six titles during his collegiate career, including the ACC tournament championship as a sophomore in 1984.[\[9\]] Professional career ------- \[[edit]\] In 1985, Love turned professional. He earned his PGA Tour card late in the season at [1985 PGA Tour Qualifying School]. It was his first attempt at [PGA Tour Qualifying school] on his first attempt. He quickly established himself on the [PGA Tour], winning his first tour event in [1987] at the [MCI Heritage Golf Classic] at [Harbour Town Golf Links]. He would later win this event four more times, setting a record for the most victories in the tournament. In 1994, Love founded Love Golf Design, a golf course architecture company with his younger brother and caddie, Mark Love. The company has been responsible for the design of several courses throughout the southeast United States. Completed in 1997, Ocean Creek is his first signature course and is located on [Fripp Island], [South Carolina].[\[10\]] Love also designed the Dunes course at Diamante in [Cabo San Lucas], [Mexico], which is ranked among _[Golf Magazine]'_s Top 100 courses in the world.[\[11\]] Love was a consistent contender and winner on the PGA Tour in the 1990s and early 2000s, but the most memorable win came at the [1997 PGA Championship], his only major championship victory. It was played at [Winged Foot Golf Club] near [New York City], and just four players in the field finished under-par for the week. Love's winning score was 11-under-par, five strokes better than runner-up [Justin Leonard]. When Love sank his birdie putt on the final hole of the championship, it was under the arc of a rainbow, which appeared as he walked up to the 18th green. In the telecast, [CBS Sports] announcer [Jim Nantz] made the connection between the rainbow and Love's late father, Davis Love Jr., who was a well-known and beloved figure in the golf world.[\[12\]][\[13\]] This victory was the last major championship win achieved with a [wooden]\-headed driver.[\[14\]] Love has had success late in his regular career. On November 9, 2008, Love earned his 20th PGA Tour win at the [Children's Miracle Network Classic], which gave him a lifetime exemption on Tour. ### Senior career \[[edit]\] After failing to qualify for the [FedEx Cup] in 2014, Love made his [Champions Tour] debut at the [Pacific Links Hawaii Championship]. Love's victory in the 2015 [Wyndham Championship]—at age 51—made him the third-oldest winne

It was from him that Love first got his passion for the game. Love’s mother also plays golf. Unfortunately Love’s father died in a plane crash in 1988. During his time at college Love was three time All-American. After turning professional in 1985, Love quickly earned his **[PGA]** Tour card. Two years later he won his first PGA Tour event, at the MCI Heritage Golf Classic, at Harbour Town Golf Links. He continued to achieve success, both on and off the course. Love has also written a successful book, Every Shot I Take, in honor of his father, which was published in 1997. The book won the United States Golf Association's International Book Award. Love is a family man; he is married to Robin, and the couple has two children. Davis Love III is a prominent figure in professional golf, known for his impressive career on the PGA Tour. **He has won 21 [PGA Tour events], including the prestigious 1997 PGA Championship, showcasing his skill and consistency on the course.**

Love has also made headlines as the third oldest winner in PGA Tour history, capturing the Wyndham Championship title at age 51, a feat that not only highlights his enduring talent but also inspires fans around the world.

His journey through the sport, marked by numerous achievements and a deep connection with fans, is especially noteworthy. As an influential player, he has contributed significantly to golf’s popularity, particularly in markets like New York, where the sport continues to grow.

Love’s experiences reflect the dedication and passion that resonate with both seasoned observers and newcomers to the game.

Who Is Davis Love III?

[Davis Love III] is a prominent American golfer known for his [successful career] on the PGA Tour. He has made a significant impact in the world of golf, not just with his victories but also through his leadership and contributions to the sport.

His life and career are marked by key milestones, from his upbringing to his family life.

### Where Did Davis Love III Grow Up?

Davis Love III was born on April 13, 1964, in Charlotte, North Carolina. He was raised in a golf-loving family, as his father, Davis Love Jr., was a golf professional and course designer.

Growing up in an environment rich in golf culture, Love developed a passion for the game at an early age.

The scenic courses of North Carolina became his playground, where he honed his skills. Moving later to the coastal area of St. Simons Island, Georgia, further influenced his love for golf, as he engaged with the vibrant golfing community in that region.

### Davis Love III’s Early Golf Career

Love’s early golf career took off during his high school years in Georgia. He won several junior tournaments and quickly attracted attention for his talent.

After high school, he attended the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. There, he played collegiate golf and earned All-American honors.

In 1985, Love turned professional after a successful amateur career. His early years on the PGA Tour were filled with challenges, but he steadily improved.

By the early 1990s, he was recognized as one of the [top players] in the world, laying the groundwork for a Hall of Fame career.

### Where Does Davis Love III Live?

Currently, Davis Love III resides in Sea Island, Georgia. This area is known for its beautiful golf courses and coastal lifestyle, making it an ideal location for a professional golfer. The lush landscapes and favorable climate allow Love to practice and enjoy golf year-round.

He also has a home in St. Simons Island, which reflects his deep connection to the region. This community has not only supported his career but has also become a significant part of his life and family traditions.

### Who Is Davis Love III Married To?

Davis Love III is married to Robin Love. The couple tied the knot in 1992, and they have been partners both in life and in supporting each other’s careers. Robin has often been by Davis’s side at events, showcasing their strong bond.

She plays an essential role in his life, providing support during his golfing endeavors. Together, they embody a partnership that has lasted through the highs and lows of Love’s professional journey.

### Does Davis Love III Have Children?

Davis and Robin Love have two children, a son named Davis IV and a daughter named Lexie. The Love family shares a love for golf, with Davis IV also pursuing the sport.

Love has emphasized the importance of family in his life. He often expresses pride in watching his children grow and develop their interests, including golf. Family time remains a priority despite the demands of his professional career.

Davis Love III - World Golf Ranking History ===== Toggle navigation [Golf Ranking Stats] * [Strokes Gained Calculator] * [Player List] Davis Love III - World Ranking History ============== ### What is Davis Love III's current world ranking? Davis Love III is not currently ranked in the top 300 of the world golf rankings. ### What is Davis Love III's peak world ranking? Davis Love III's peak world ranking occured on May 17, 1999, when he was ranked #2 with 10.720 world ranking points. ### Has Davis Love III been ranked number 1? No, Davis Love III has never been ranked #1 in the world. The closest he came was on May 17, 1999 when he was ranked #2. ### How many weeks has Davis Love III been ranked in the top 10? How many Major Championships has Davis Love III won?
===== 

[]

* [Categories]
  
  [Recent Golf Quiz Questions] [Celebrities and Entertainment in Golf] [Golf Courses of the World] [Champions of the Game] [Equipment] [Golf History] [The Majors] [Playing the Game] [Recent and Upcoming Events] [Rules of Golf] [Women's Golf]
  
* [Quiz]
* [Search]
* [Newsletter]

[NEWSLETTER]

How many Majors has Davis Love III won?
=============

Davis Love III won one Major, the 1997 PGA Championship.

More about Davis Love III's Major Championship Win
------------------

Davis Milton Love III was born on 13th April, 1964 in Charlotte, North Carolina, one day after his father played in the final round of the 1964 Masters Tournament.

He turned professional in 1985.

In 1994 he founded a golf course architecture company, with his younger brother and caddie, Mark Love.

Davis Love III holds 1 Major Championship title, 2 Players Championship titles and 18 other PGA Tour wins.

### 1997 PGA Championshi

Davis won the 1997 PGA Championship at Winged Foot, 5 strokes ahead of runner up [Justin Leonard].

His total score was 269 (-11).

The winner's share was $470,000.

Published Time: 2022-03-05T11:02:59Z

Davis Love III's golf career forever linked to Players Championship
=====
 

[]

[]

[]

[News] [Sports] [Entertainment] [Lifestyle] [Opinion] [Advertise] [Obituaries] [eNewspaper] [Legals]

[]

[][]

[]

[][]

GOLF

Two-time Players champ Davis Love III has built legacy of service from Golden Isles to First Coast
==================================

Love won two Players nine years apart during a Hall of Fame career that has included triumph and tragedy
------------------------------------

 [![Image 1: Portrait of Garry Smits] Garry Smits]

Florida Times-Union

[][][](mailto:?subject=Two-time%20Players%20champ%20Davis%20Love%20III%20has%20built%20legacy%20of%20service%20from%20Golden%20Isles%20to%20First%20Coast%20-%20from%20The%20Florida%20Times-Union&body=Two-time%20Players%20champ%20Davis%20Love%20III%20has%20built%20legacy%20of%20service%20from%20Golden%20Isles%20to%20First%20Coast%0A%0AThirty%20years%20after%20Davis%20Love%20III%20won%20the%20first%20of%20his%20two%20Players%20Championships%2C%20he%20knows%20getting%20into%20Hall%20of%20Fame%20was%20a%20product%20of%20those%20victories.%0A%0ACheck%20out%20this%20story%20on%20jacksonville.com%3A%20https%3A%2F%2Fwww.jacksonville.com%2Fstory%2Fsports%2Fgolf%2F2022%2F03%2F05%2Fdavis-love-iiis-golf-career-forever-linked-players-championship%2F6895742001%2F)

![Image 2]

0:00

0:46

AD

SKIP

[![Image 3]]The measure of the golfer establishes Davis Love III as one of the biggest stars of the pre-Tiger Woods era and beyond: more than three dozen worldwide victories, winner of two Players Championships, the 1997 PGA Championship, a participant on 13 U.S. international match-play teams, winning Ryder Cup captain and member of the World Golf Hall of Fame.

The measure of the man goes far beyond earnings, trophies and titles. It’s seen in a PGA Tour event he hosts in his adopted hometown that has raised more than $25 million in charity, numerous other charitable efforts both seen and unseen, being honored with the PGA Tour’s Payne Stewart Award that counts character more than birdies, signing every autograph and posing for every picture or merely throwing a chain saw in the back of his truck and cutting fallen tree limbs down so his neighbors can get out after a hurricane.

It also can be found in 35 years of marriage, two children and three grandchildren and quite simply being beloved for being himself, from the Golden Isles to the First Coast.

30 years later: [Davis Love III still cherishes memory of proving a pair of fans wrong]

It's gonna be packed: [Time to move fast for Players tickets, parking as return to full capacity creating high demand]

Need a break? [Play the USA TODAY Daily Crossword Puzzle.]

Saban surprise: [Justin Thomas returns to the scene of his biggest 2021 victory — and gets a surprise visit]

Two-time major champion Zach Johnson spoke for the two dozen or so professionals who have set up home bases on St. Simons Island, Ga., partly due to the influence of the man they call, with humor and affection, "Uncle Davis."

"The more I can be around him, the better off I'll be," Johnson said about Davis Love III, golfer, businessman, architect, philanthropist, husband, father, grandfather, mentor and friend.

Synonymous with The Players  
-----------

There have been five men to win The Players Championship twice at the Players Stadium Course at TPC Sawgrass: Love, Fred Couples, Steve Elkington, Hal Sutton and Tiger Woods. Love won his titles nine years apart, the longest time between victories, and came from behind in both with final rounds of 67 in 1992 and a record closing round for a winner of 64 in 20003.

This year is the 30th anniversary of Love's first Players victory, which was the fourth of his 21 PGA Tour titles and his first victory in a huge event with an elite field. He had to catch and pass Nick Faldo in the final round, no small feat.

In a way, it was his coming-out party but Love already had won twice at Hilton Head and had been tabbed as one of the rising Tour stars since he was a three-time All-American and Walker Cup player at North Carolina.

![Image 4: Davis Love III waves to fans as he walks to the pin after chipping his ball from the gallery behind the eighth green into the hole for birdie and the lead during the final round of the 1992 Players Championship. He went on to win by four shots. [Bob Self/Florida Times-Union]]

Love is tied with Jay Haas for the most career starts on The Players with 29, is tied for second with Sergio Garcia for the most top-10s with seven and has made the fourth-most cuts with 19.

Love even went to The Players before turning pro: the first date with his wife outside of the beach or a fast-food meal on St. Simons Island was to take her for a day at the 1982 Players Championship.

"She came out in flip-flops and I showed her around the course and said, 'this is what I'm going to do for a living,'" Love said. "She told me, 'yeah, right.'"

Now settled into a life where his most serious competitive desires will be found on the PGA Tour Champions (and if he finally breaks free of a series of injuries), the only role this week at The Players for the 57-year-old Love will be ceremonial: he's the World Golf Hall of Fame member who will present former PGA Tour commissioner Tim Finchem at the March 9 induction ceremony at the PGA Tour Global Home.

![Image 5: Davis Love III has made his biggest impact in golf by winning The Players Championship twice and guiding the U.S. to victory in the 2016 Ryder Cup.]

Love's 36-year association with the Tour's gold standard event, his two titles and the dashing and daring manner in which he won them has often led to some confusion: as iconic a figure as he is on the Golden Isles of Georgia, some fans mistakenly think he lives in Jacksonville or Ponte Vedra Beach.

"It's always felt like a home game," Love said of The Players. "It's so close to St. Simons. Plus, I've been on the \[PGA Tour Policy\] board so many times \[five\] that I'm here a lot. And Dad brought us down here to play all the time when Mark \[his brother and former caddie\] and I were kids. It was a nice little trip for us. We'd go play the Sawgrass Country Club, then the new course."

Love's comfort zone  
-------

The “new course” being the Stadium, and Love quickly became enamored with the challenges of the Pete Dye design — the asymmetrical lines off fairways, the forced carries over water, pot bunkers, undulating fairways and greens — a version of Dye's Harbour Town Golf Links on Hilton Head Island, S.C., where Love has won five times.

"I loved Pete Dye courses, loved the challenge, loved the grasses," Love said.

![Image 6: Davis Love III is greeted by his wife Robin and their 9-year-old son Dru after he won his second Players Championship in 2003.]

Love tied for 14th in The Players in his first attempt, in 1986. He then had some stumbles, with two missed cuts and a disqualification in 1988 for signing an incorrect scorecard but when he passed Faldo with a series of clutch putts and short-game shots in 1992, Love cemented his status as one of the Tour's biggest stars. He won three times that year and finished second to Fred Couples on the money list.

"Davis' game fit that course as well as anyone I ever saw," Couples said.

Fred Funk, another past Players champion, said the way to conquer the Stadium Course and win The Players is to not back down from Dye's design.

"Pete designs courses that are visually intimidating ... he wants you to be intimidated," Funk said. "Davis never got intimidated by anything. He was successful on that course early and success kept breeding success."

Love didn't want to get into the debate about whether The Players should be considered a major championship but he said when it comes time to tee it up and play 72 holes on a championship course, the tournament doesn't take a back seat to any challenge.

"The biggest thing to most players, even back then, is how stron
